comments.commentBody: Although you say that you would like to think that if Griner were on Kentucky's Mens team, she would still decide to forgo pro ball, I think she would never have played for Calipari in the first place.  She seems like the type of student-athlete that would have played for Coach K at Duke or Johnny Dawkins at Stanford.

Me too. However, I don't have the stamina to do that everyday.  Most Americans don't have the time, either, unless they're unemployed, with no dependents, or any other responsibilities.  It takes me at least five to six hours to walk that much.  How many people do you know who can devote that much time to simply walking?

Funny post.  But I bet that early humans sat around plenty, just not on modern chairs and sofas.  It's perfectly possible to sit on the ground (perhaps on a fur, then later a cloth mat or rug, as we progressed toward modern life.  Plenty of contemporary cultures still sit on the floor, right?)  Maybe we also spent time squatting, too (which is actually very comfortable if you're accustomed to doing so.)

Why not point out that Lizzy walked several miles "cross country" to visit Caroline in the first place, and thought nothing of it, despite inclement weather?

And Jane Austen wrote Pride and Prejudice in 1796 and 1797, when she was twenty-one and twenty-two years old, though the novel wasn't published until 1813.
Try a kneeling chair.
Juvenile (type 1) diabetes is an autism spectrum disorder? References to medical journal articles about this, please.

I agree.

Vaccines and Brain Inflammation

"The Pourcyrous Study: A Major Milestone in Medical History

A study on primary immunization of 239 premature infants with gestational ages of less than 35 weeks by M. Pourcyrous et al. (Journal of Pediatrics, 2007) [23] was conducted to determine the incidence of cardio-respiratory events and abnormal C-Reaction Protein (CRP) elevations associated with administration of a single vaccine or multiple vaccines simultaneously at or about two months of age. The vaccines given were: DTaP (Infanrix), Hib (ActHIB), HBV (Engerix-B), IPV (Inactivated-IPOL™), and PCV7 (Prevnar).

CRP is a standard blood test indicator for body inflammation, which in the present study would represent brain inflammation. CRP levels and cardio-respiratory manifestations were monitored for three days following immunizations in a neonatal intensive care unit sponsored by the University of Tennessee. Elevations of CRP levels occurred in 70 percent of the infants administered single vaccines and in 85 percent of those administered multiple vaccines, 43 percent of which reached abnormal levels."

www.vaccinationcouncil.org/2011/06/01/vaccines-and-brain-inflammation/

Yeah, let's do away with vaccines - then we'll see what epidemics are really about! We'll see how infectious diseases drastically reduce the population - with highest mortality among young children, the elderly, & those already vulnerable due to disease & compromised immunity.

Yup, we'll save a lot of money on social security & Medicare when so many of our elderly succumb! & just think what we'll save when all the cancer & AIDS patients die off!

And we won't be worried about autism once millions of babies & children fall ill & die too!

Of course, there's still the problem that many of those pesky ol' diseases mostly prevented now by vaccines - such as measles, rubella, meningitis & polio -don't always kill - often they leave their victims blind, deaf, severely brain damaged, paralyzed, etc.

Sigh... as I wrote in a previous comment, there's no point trying to reason with these anti-vaccinators any more than with birthers. This anti-vaccination, anti-science belief has become a religious cult - & its devotees cannot be swayed by facts or science - not even by the scientific debunking of this belief & the exposure of its originator as a fraud.

The big problem for the rest of us is that they're willing to sacrifice the health & lives of millions of people to this belief.

My son was vaccinated for everything, including whooping cough.

But because we lived in downtown Manhattan at the time (2004), where lots of ignorant crunchy-granola-type hipsters felt they were smarter than their kids' doctors and too groovy to vaccinate, new strains of whooping cough developed, and when my son was 3 1/2 his vaccine failed to protect him from one of them.

For 3 weeks straight, he woke up at about 2:30AM with a coughing fit so bad it made him throw up. He also had coughing fits all during the day, which also often made him throw up. The coughing fits wracked his small body with their violence. If my son tried to run, after just a few steps, he'd get a coughing fit and have to stop. Sometimes simply going out into the cool air in the evening would cause a coughing fit. We were vacationing at a summer beach resort when the disease hit, and had to go home early. Our (top-notch Fifth Avenue) pediatrician didn't recognize the illness, because he hadn't seen pertussis in so many years. In fact, it was a NYT article about these so-called "breakout infections" of pertussis that I read that suddenly made a light bulb go off in my head (thanks, NYT).

By then, there was nothing to be done but to wait it out. The cough took almost 6 months to slowly fade away. My son was unable to run and play outside normally for the first 3 of those months.

Perhaps this will give you an idea of how infuriating I find ignorant, unsubstantiated comments like yours.
Vaccines are the cause of this epidemic.

Autism is not a mental health issue; it is a neurological and developmental disorder. Spend some time with autistic people and their families, and this will be obvious.

Pathogenic parenting causes all kinds of problems -- but autism is not one of them.

Pointing out that autism is not the product of bad parenting is not the same thing as ignoring the very real, but quite different, damage done by abusive or neglectful parenting.

TO HOward:

It's true that Bettleheim's ideas about "refrigerator mothers" are not valid or as you put it, "soundly debunked" for classical autism, but when you look at "mission creep" overdiagnosis, you see many kinds of conditions traceable to early development.

One has to ask: What does happen to children of cold, unloving mothers and fathers, or abusive/cruel/negligent parents? You seem to believe: 1. Nothing. There is no impact. Or 2. These kinds of parents don't exist.

The fact is pathogenic parenting does happen and it has a huge deleterious impact on children's mental health. Children's brains are highly responsive to interpersonal experiences, including negative ones. Like it or not. If that's guilt-inducing, then we have to deal with the guilt -- maybe it will make for better cargivers.
There is a correlation between the use of cell phones and just about any other parameter that has also risen within the last decade.  Strong work.

Matt, maybe one answer is that we don't all HAVE to have children at all, at any age - maybe there's nothing wrong with having other priorities in life. You're right - most of us find we can't have it all - & maybe, if we're honest with ourselves, we know that we really don't want to.

One message I get from this article is that autism is a complex group of disorders that likely have multiple causes. Age alone may not be the determining factor. In any case, this research shows that scientists are making some progress in gaining understanding of these disorders. But clearly, the science isn't yet at the point of providing clear lifestyle advice, as in "stop smoking to reduce your chances of getting cancer."

So no, Daisy, this is not information meant for you to rely on to make choices about your life. It's interesting information about serious scientific research - & it's good to know that various possible factors are being studied.
No.  It's not the household servitude.   It's the female hormones.  There's nothing whatsoever redeeming about household work.
Past generations had large families and parents were having children, perhaps a 6th or 7th, well into their thirties, sometimes 40's, yet the incidence of autism  was not as prevelant as now.
Thank you for this! I will save these comments and read them often.

I kind of hate it when people with decent marriages advise others to "stay married".  If only it were that simple!  I get that you shouldn't break up over a few arguments, but if your spouse of many years changes and becomes, say a violent, crazy, unemployed alcoholic, you may have to move on for the sake of your kids.

"Go into careers that permit both parents to work at 50 percent capacity, while still providing family heath care benefits"

Ha! Hate to rain on your parade, but those jobs largely don't exist... I've never worked for any company that offered health insurance to people working less than 40 hours a week. (I think Starbucks is about the only exception, but most people can't raise a family on a part-time barista wage).

Also, if everyone takes your advice, where are we going to get doctors, scientists, etc.?

To the new generation: Have your children early, but not too early.
Marry your high school sweetheart, or someone young and dear like that, the one with whom your young pheromones were mutually most attractive, and before birth control pills blunted their secretion and detection.
Go into careers that permit both parents to work at 50 percent capacity, while still providing family heath care benefits, so you can both have quality time with your kids.
Avoid careers that expect or require you to make concessions on these points, such as Medicine, which will require a decade of 100 hour weeks after college, just to complete your training.
Stay married. If you follow your instincts and marry the one you are biologically most attracted to, you can make it work. Get marriage counseling if you hit a rough patch, but don't give up -- whatever the issues were, they would be there in another relationship anyway.
Play with your kids -- a lot. Get down on the floor. Let them play hop on pop on you. Blow Razzie sounds on their tummies, let them stick their fingers into your nose. Read to them, keep the TV off. Listen to music, go on hikes.
Work, and save. Get them summer jobs, and put all of their earnings into an IRA in their name.
Be the first one to offer to drive your kids and their friends to a party, you will learn a lot.
And don't worry that it is still not quite good enough, relax. Life goes by so fast, we are really all just kids, learning as we go.
Be gentle with yourselves.

They are doing everything possible to discredit older parents

Our only chance at avoiding a demographic collapse.

This is rare and should not impede child bearing

Mercury was PREVIOUSLY added to vaccines - in extremely tiny amounts - as a preservative. It has been eliminated in vaccines for some 10 years. And there's been no correlation in rates of autism among children who received the vaccines with the mercury & those who received vaccines without it - & those who were not vaccinated at all.

Except of course, that children who were not vaccinated at all are more likely to contract vaccine-preventable infectious diseases - & infect others.

The article points to one possible factor - age of fathers - but does not imply that is the sole cause.

Perhaps you're just disappointed that this article does not implicate vaccines as a cause of autism? Study after study - in several countries - have shown NO correlation between vaccines and autism. That question has been answered - again & again & again. Time to move on.
I thought this article was about cats! How disappointing.

This is good news for those of us with jobs in front of a computer! Slight modifications in our inactive time can make us healthier, even without running a marathon. I see these two studies in very positive way. There are lots of ways to change it up.
Check out: www.cogfit.net or www.freshoffthecouch.com for some more ideas.
If I'm going have to stand all the time, I don't think I'll want to live so much longer.
LOVE the sleeping kitty picture that came with this article.  If I could stay in as good a shape as my cat does, and still get as much rest and loving as she gets, man, life would be grand!
Get an iPad and take the Internet with you to the gym.

I blame every pound I have gained since 1994 on the Internet, the year I got a new laptop that allowed me to join AOL.

I have spent far more time than I ever would have imagined since then, sitting in front of a screen, and no longer watch TV.

The Internet (does anyone still capitalize the word?) is far more enticing than the gym.

I'll tell you what, I certainly do “substitute either lighter and/or sedentary activities” after a few hours of suffering in the saddle of my bicycle. Some call it 'recovery'. I call it 'survival'.

In fact, most any amature athelete will recognize the mantra 'don't stand if you can sit; don't sit if you can lie, don't lie awake if you can sleep'...

How can you say we have been shielded when it is President Obama who signed the NDAA that clearly takes away all rights of American citizens? I voted for him, I worked for him, I was so happy when he won.

What happened to that man?

Mr. Etch-a-Sketch Romney's problem is that the primaries have shown exactly what sort of politician he is. Romney is not the moderate that he pretended to be in Massachusetts. And he may not actually be the rabidly reactionary conservative he played in the primaries. Instead, Romney is a candidate who lacks any core values, principles, or beliefs and, therefore, will do say or do anything if he thinks it will win him votes, even if it is the exact opposite of what he said or did the day before.

In normal times, having such an empty cipher might be merely disappointing. But these are not normal times. Instead, these are times when our nation faces major issues about war, jobs, social issues, and deficits, yet one of the two major political parties - the GOP - has gone completely off the rails.

To date, our nation has been largely shielded by President Obama from the harm that could be caused by the wingnuts who have overtaken the GOP. But if Romney were to become President, he has shown he would be entirely unable to stand up to these same wingnuts. Romney had a chance to stand up for the rational, reality based conservatism of his father's GOP, but he didn't. Instead, Romney joined the crazy and cheerleaded it on. Imagine what he would do as President in response to reactionary proposals from House Republicans the conservative echo chamber.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236
Praise God!
When it comes to cancer, statistics are here to tell us what the outcome has been, in the past, for a group of people. In no way can statistics predict the future, let alone one person's future.

I hope all is well. You are in my prayers for complete healing. My son Ben who is 23 was diagnosed with Chrondrosarcoma in the sternum last June. He had his manubrium removed (the upper sternum) and reconstructed . We have to go to Boston next tuesday for a cat scan. This has changed his and our lives. He is healing more every day but it was rough to go through. He asked if he was a cancer survivor even though he didn't go through chemo or radiation as it doesn't respond to either. He actually felt guilty about this. He is very good at math and statistics and states statistics related to his potential for death. It is a real problem for him to deal with. As a Mom my instinct is to protect and I know God will be with him always and you too. Trust him and call on him for strength and protection when its rough. He will help you. I believe God to be the best chance of survival no matter what. He just wants to get on with his life, when he has applied for jobs and explains his break in employment they don't ever call him back. He can only lift 50 lbs as he has to wait for everything to strengthen up. He will find something. In my thoughts and prayers.
Carol
Suleika: You are a hero. Hang in there.
